CONJUGATES: melancholies (noun plural) | more melancholy (adjective comparative) | most melancholy (adjective superlative)
ETYMOLOGY: From Old French melancolie, from Late Latin melancholia, from Greek melancholia 'black bile,' from melas 'black' + khole 'bile' (regarded as the cause of gloominess).

MEANINGS.PATTERN: a feeling of melancholy | full of melancholy
MEANINGS.POS_TIP: a word (other than a pronoun) used to identify any of a class of people, places, or things (common noun), or to name a particular one of these (proper noun).
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: A feeling of pensive sadness, typically with no obvious cause.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 一种沉思的、通常没有明显原因的悲伤情绪；忧郁。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: He experienced a deep sense of melancholy after his friend moved away.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 朋友搬走后，他感到深深的忧郁。

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: a word naming an attribute of a noun.
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: Characterized by or causing a state of deep, pensive sadness; gloomy.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 具有或引起深沉、沉思的悲伤状态的；忧郁的，悲伤的。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: The melancholy song perfectly captured his mood.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 这首忧郁的歌完美地表达了他的心情。

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: a word (other than a pronoun) used to identify any of a class of people, places, or things (common noun), or to name a particular one of these (proper noun).
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: (Historical, medical) A mental condition characterized by extreme depression, often with delusions and hallucinations, believed in ancient and medieval medicine to be caused by an excess of black bile.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: （历史医学）一种以极度抑郁、常伴有妄想和幻觉为特征的精神疾病，古希腊和中世纪医学认为是由过量的黑胆汁引起。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: In Shakespearean times, melancholy was sometimes seen as a fashionable affliction.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 在莎士比亚时代，忧郁有时被视为一种时髦的病痛。
